The safety and security of our students and employees is our main priority in Conecuh County Schools. Across the state and country, school leaders are making tough decisions about how to reopen schools as concerns grow regarding the increase in Coronavirus cases.
We are seeking your input in order to determine the best option for our students and employees. At this time, approximately 600 parents/guardians have completed our declaration survey for the upcoming school year. Approximately 40% of families have chosen the traditional option (face-to-face instruction) and about 60% have chosen the remote option (online learning). The results have also indicated that over 40% of our students, do not have access to internet at home. This means that online (remote)education could be extremely difficult.

With that in mind, Conecuh County Board of Education is anticipating offering a holistic approach, which includes a choice of either remote(online) or a traditional approach. With the holistic approach, we are trying to address the needs of all families.

As concerns continue to grow and with the rapid changes, we need to hear from ALL of our parents and guardians. If you have not completed our parental declaration survey, we are asking that you please take the time to complete it now. Thank you for your input.
Please find the link below:

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1SeZVpyP7SQmROilSFbS_BI-cTGfTGfQruQu1o_70D4I

Good afternoon, we have received numerous calls regarding
Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP). We hope this information is found to be helpful.

Please know that all students in Conecuh County qualify for this program. However, the time in which your receive benefits may be different. Please see the information below for details:

All P-EBT cards and instructions will be sent from DHR as follows:
SNAP Recipients (Current Recipients)
P-EBT benefits will be added to the recipient’s SNAP card.

For families that are not current SNAP Recipients.

DHR will send a letter in the mail before May 31. Once you receive your letter, the family must provide information to DHR per instructions in the letter to receive benefits. DHR will provide information on how to receive a PIN for the card.

An important item to note from the press release:

* Information from DHR will be sent to the address provided to the school. If you have an old address on file and have not provided a current address to the school, you should contact DHR or provide a current address to the school.

* This is a multi-phase project that is expected to take several weeks to complete. After May 31, 2020, households who have not received a P-EBT letter or card and believe that they were eligible and were possibly omitted during the automation process, please contact DHR P-EBT Customer Service at: 1-800-410-5827 or email DHR with inquiries at: PEBT@dhr.alabama.gov.

Attention Students and Parents:

We want you to know that we miss you. We miss your smiles, your chatter, your questions, your hugs, your faces. We miss watching you grow up. We truly miss ALL of you. Times are uncertain for everyone right now, but we want you to know that we will continue to be here for you as best we can through this. We are STILL here.

Employees of the Conecuh County Board of Education have worked tirelessly through Spring Break, the weekends, and all this week to ensure that we do our part to continue to provide you with a quality education. Our teachers and staff also came to work today to finalize plans to ensure that you have access to teaching and learning through paper/pencil and/or online methods. We were careful to practice social distancing during our meetings today. We hope that you all are being safe as well.

Beginning Monday, April 6th, teaching and learning will continue while you are away from school. Each school will provide you with at-home paper/pencil, textbook/workbook, and online options through 4th quarter. Your assignments will be graded, so it important that you do your very best and follow directions from your teacher.

You will receive additional information from the school via social media, email, Remind, and the school website. It’s also important that we have the most current contact information for parents and students.

If you have not heard from your teachers already, they will reach out to you no later than Monday, April 6th. Be safe and remember: In Conecuh, we are GREAT... Whatever it takes!!!

Due to new information provided by the Alabama Department of Public Health (ADPH) which has advised to restrict gatherings of 50 or more people, all Conecuh County Schools WILL CLOSE at the end of business TODAY, March 16, 2020 and will not reopen until the tentative state recommended re-open date of April 6, 2020. In the meantime, a preview of the blank remote learning plans is available in the pictures accompanying this post.

Our district is providing these Emergency Remote Learning Plans so that our students and parents will have access to textbooks, workbooks, consumable resources, and other educational resources if they choose to continue reviewing and learning what has been taught this year. Again, the assignments in the remote learning plans are OPTIONAL and are only provided in efforts to support a sense of normalcy and structure for our students during this extended break.

Please stand-by for more updates from your child's school via school and district websites, Facebook, email, and Remind. Our district is committed to ensuring that our students and employees are safe and that students have optional learning opportunities at home to remain engaged in learning during the extended break. Be safe.

Attention Employees, Parents, & Students:

Alabama Governor Kay Ivey has issued a State of Emergency declaration for Alabama in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. In efforts to keep our employees, students, and school communities safe, we will adhere to Gov. Kay Ivey's state-wide school closure statement as follows:

Schools will close effective Wednesday, March 18th at the end of the school day.
Schools are tentatively set to reopen on April 6th.

Please keep in mind that students' and employees' return date to work may change based on Gov. Ivey's formal statements that will be issued over the next few days and weeks. We are continuously monitoring this situation and are in contact with state and government officials to ensure that we are providing updates as soon as possible.

Students whose parents choose not to send them to school on Monday, Tuesday, or Wednesday of next week due to health concerns over the coronavirus pandemic, will be automatically marked as "present at home." This will minimize the stress on teachers, parents, and data entry personnel to collect excuse letters from parents upon students' return to school.

We will utilize the district's Facebook page and the Remind App to communicate updates to employees, parents, and students. Our thoughts and prayers are with all of our employees, students, parents, and community.

Sincerely,

Dr. Zickeyous Byrd, Superintendent
Conecuh County Board of Education

The Conecuh County Board of Education has maintained fiscal transparency since 2015 when our Superintendent required the documents be made available to the public via our district's website. We believe that the finances of our district belong to our students and that our stakeholders should always be able to access our public records. Our district has been audited at state and federal levels multiple times throughout the years AND has received commendations for our accounting practices. If you ever wish to view our financial statements they are (and have been since 2015) accessible by following these steps:
1.) Go to www.conecuh.k12.al.us
2.) Select "Departments" from the 3rd tab at the top of the website.
3.) Under "Finance" on the left-side of the screen, select "Document Uploads."
4.) Select "Financial & Accountability Reports."
5.) You will find our district's financials and accountability reports to be at your fingertips and only a few clicks away!

In Conecuh, we are GREAT (and fiscally transparent)... Whatever it takes!!!

A message regarding Alabama’s Failing School List.
Dr. Zickeyous Byrd

Although Hillcrest High School (HHS) has shown a steady increase in their Alabama A-F Report card over the last several years, including this year, we have learned today that they have been listed as a failing school based on the Alabama Legislature’s Accountability Act. It can be quite confusing to understand how HHS can be designated as a failing school, even though their scores improved.

According to the Alabama Department of Education’s (ALSDE) website, “Alabama's Accountability System is a unified approach to meeting the requirements of Every Student Succeeds Act (ESSA) and Alabama Act 2012-402. Federal law mandates the use of various indicators for meaningful differentiation among schools while Alabama Act 2012-402 requires the State Superintendent to develop a school grading system which is also known as “Alabama’s A-F Report Card.”

In addition to the ALSDE’s A-F Report Card score, the Alabama Legislature is also required to identify failing schools which are the schools that ranked in the lowest 6% on the Alabama A-F Report Card. This means that even if ALL Alabama Schools were to make A’s and B’s on the A-F Report Card, the schools with the lowest B’s would be deemed failing schools. This is the reason HHS has improved, does NOT have a failing score of an F, but is still named a failing school. Confusing, right?

The failing schools designation is the result of one snapshot of one test (the ACT) taken by last year’s 11th graders across the state who are now 12th graders. The Scantron Assessment was used for last year’s 3rd-8th graders. It’s horrible to think that the legislature would allow one test, on one day, for one grade level for a high school to determine a so-called “failing” status of a school. We don’t fail students based on one assessment, so it is also unfair for schools and districts to be graded and deemed as failing in this manner. For us, HHS, it’s teachers, and students are far from failing. HHS has improved and will continue to improve!

Consider the data trends at HHS: In 2016-2017, HHS earned a 68/D and was not a failing school. In 2017-2018, HHS earned a 63/D and was not a failing school. However, in 2018-2019, HHS demonstrated 5% in gains with a score of 68/D, which is one of the highest rates of growth in the district, and is now designated a failing school.

No, we’re not happy with a 68, but we do see huge improvements and we are confident that our scores will be even higher for next year. Hillcrest has always met every challenge with great resilience and might and will do it again this year. Our students and staff understand the mission and I guarantee you this will only be a “one year” designation. Like always, we’re going to show everyone the pride of Jagnation and the Power House of the South!!

Encouragement from Mr. Daffin, HHS Principal

We remain optimistic about the progress HHS has made and will continue to make. The failing schools designation is unfair, but the state legislature is required by law to make the designation for the bottom 6% of all public Alabama schools. According to Mr. Daffin, HHS Principal, “This is a new year. We will use the information from last year’s scores to inform us of what we need to do for this year. We will continue to provide resources, support, and opportunities for our students to shine in academics, on assessments, and through the arts and extra-curricular activities. We are implementing test-taking skills and intervention periods, as well as new learning software that will address students’ individual academic needs in reading and mathematics. Hopefully all of our improvement efforts will be reflected in the upcoming spring data.”
